title: Chiles Rellenos (Cheese)
description: Classic Mexican stuffed poblano peppers filled with melted cheese, lightly battered and fried until golden, served with a bright tomato-based salsa. Rich, creamy interior balanced by smoky charred peppers and a crisp exterior.

ingredients.display_name: queso fresco or Oaxaca cheese (or Monterey Jack)
ingredients.notes: cut into 8 equal sticks or slices

ingredients.display_name: all-purpose flour (for batter - optional double dredge)

ingredients.notes: use cold milk to loosen batter if needed
about 2.5 cups or enough for 1/2 inch in skillet

ingredients.display_name: vegetable oil or olive oil (for roasting/charring)
ingredients.notes: to rub on peppers before charring

steps.text: Char the poblano peppers over a gas burner, under a broiler, or on a hot cast-iron skillet until the skins are blackened and blistered on all sides; this takes about 8–10 minutes, turning frequently to get even charring.
Place the charred peppers in a bowl and cover tightly with plastic wrap or a lid to steam for 10 minutes to loosen skins.
Carefully peel off the loosened skins, slit each pepper lengthwise without cutting through completely, remove seeds and membranes as desired to reduce heat, and pat dry with paper towels.
Stuff each pepper with an even portion of cheese (use strips that fit inside), then close the pepper gently and secure with a toothpick if necessary.
Season the cheese-stuffed peppers lightly with salt and pepper on the exterior and set on a tray while preparing batter and oil.

Make the batter by whipping the egg whites with a pinch of salt (and optional baking powder) until glossy stiff peaks form, then fold in the yolks gently along with a few tablespoons of flour to stabilize; if desired, whisk a small amount of milk into yolks before folding for a looser batter.
Heat a wide skillet with about 1/2 inch of oil over medium heat until it reaches 180°C/360°F or a small piece of batter sizzles and rises slowly (about 3–4 minutes to heat).
Dredge each stuffed pepper lightly in flour to coat (shake off excess), then dip into the egg batter to fully coat, allowing excess to drip off before frying.

Fry peppers in batches, 2–3 minutes per side, until batter is puffed and golden brown; maintain oil temperature between medium and medium-high to avoid burning. Transfer to a paper-towel-lined tray to drain.

While frying, make a simple fresh salsa by pulsing or finely chopping the tomatoes, combining with chopped onion, minced garlic, cilantro, lime juice and a pinch of salt and pepper; taste and adjust seasoning.
Serve chiles rellenos hot, topped or accompanied with fresh tomato salsa and additional cilantro or crema if desired. Remove any toothpicks before serving.
